citeinfo.title: KARST_DYE_PTS_IN: Input and Detection Points for Selected Subsurface Dye Traces in Southern Indiana (Indiana Geological Survey, 1:24,000, Point Shapefile)
citeinfo.othercit: A predecessor of this shapefile (i.e., a coverage named DYE_PTS) was used in the publication of the following map: Frushour, S.S., Harper, D., and Dintaman, C., 2000, Selected subsurface dye traces in south-central Indiana, Indiana Geological Survey, Miscellaneous Map 66.

descript.abstract: KARST_DYE_PTS_IN is a point shapefile that shows the locations of input and detection points that were used for selected subsurface dye-trace investigations in southern Indiana. This shapefile should be used in conjunction with an associated shapefile named KARST_DYE_LINES_IN, which shows inferred connections between dye-trace points.
descript.purpose: KARST_DYE_PTS_IN was derived from a coverage named "DYE_PTS." The purpose of DYE_PTS was to compile unpublished work maps of Samuel S. Frushour (Indiana Geological Survey, IGS) and to bring those maps to publication by IGS.

idinfo.native: ESRI ArcView 3.2 shapefile format, approximately 27 Kb

attracc.attraccr: Internal attributes are based on work maps of Samuel S. Frushour (Indiana Geological Survey, IGS) and are assumed to be accurate. Trace information was compiled by Frushour from written field records, field maps, published reports, personal communications, and unpublished reports, and from persons with whom Frushour had collaborated.

dataqual.complete: Traces were done by use of organic dyes or other substances. All dye-detection locations were at springs or karst windows, and dye-injection locations were either at sinkholes, sinking streams, or underground cave streams. Unsuccessful attempts to trace subsurface ground-water movement (when dyes were injected but never detected) are not shown. Also, additional traces exist that are not shown.

horizpa.horizpar: No records exist regarding the horizontal positional accuracy of this shapefile. The coordinates used in georeferencing DYE_PTS (the predecessor of KARST_DYE_PTS_IN) were derived from full-size Xerox copies of 1:24,000 USGS topographic quadrangle maps. No quantitative tests were performed.

vertacc.vertaccr: Vertical positional accuracy was not a factor in the production of this shapefile.

citeinfo.title: Selected Subsurface Dye Traces in Southern Indiana
citeinfo.othercit: KARST_DYE_PTS_IN was compiled from unpublished work maps provided by Samuel S. Frushour (Indiana Geological Survey).

srcinfo.srccontr: Unpublished full-size xerographic copies of 1:24,000 topographic quadrangle maps on which input, detection, and intermediate points of selected subsurface dye-trace investigations had been plotted.

procstep.procdesc: Trace information was compiled by Samuel S. Frushour (Indiana Geological Survey, IGS). Frushour plotted points on copies of 1:24,000 topographic quadrangle maps. Full-size xerographic copies of the work maps were made. Traces were digitized from the copies by Chris Dintaman (IGS). A point coverage, named DYE_PTS, was created showing locations where dye was either introduced or detected.
procstep.srcused: xerographic copies of selected 1:24,000 topographic quadrangle maps

procstep.procdesc: The original coverage, DYE_PTS, was reprojected using NAD83. This coverage was then clipped to another coverage named INCLP83, a boundary coverage for the State of Indiana (compiled at a scale of 1:24,000). The resulting shapefile was named KARST_DYE_PTS_IN.

This metadata was pre-parsed and parsed using CNS (Chew and Spit, v 2.6.1) and MP (Metadata Parser, v 2.7.1) software written by Peter N. Schweitzer (United States Geological Survey). The errors generated by MP were all addressed and corrected, except that no values were assigned to "Abscissa_Resolution" and "Ordinate_Resolution."

attr.attrdef: Name of feature (if known) where dye was introduced or detected
Identification number for an individual trace investigation. "999" indicates that no identification number was assigned.

metainfo.metuc: This metadata file is intended to accompany the data set identified and received from the IGS. It should not to be altered or summarized. IGS does not support secondary distribution. If this data set was received from anyone besides the IGS, this metadata file and the data set it describes may lack integrity.
